economic_context.details: Esdeline came from extreme poverty - abandoned by father as child, begged for 3-4 years before able to work as servant. Accusations include theft and purse-cutting (which she admitted to one instance and made restitution). Class tension visible in the dancing incident where she insisted 'rich and poor must dance together.'

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a remarkable trial showing class tensions and the importance of local reputation. Many witnesses testified that Esdeline was NOT a witch despite quarrels with her. The apothecary's children incident appears to be the catalyst for accusations. Esdeline's extreme poverty background (abandoned child, beggar) and her controversial religious statements created vulnerability. The Change de Nancy's decision to release her (renvoyée) rather than follow PG des Vosges' recommendation for flogging and banishment is significant - they ruled she had 'sufficiently purged the accusations.' Physical evidence of torture resistance documented (bleeding from hands and feet). Notable absence of confession despite torture.
